Award.AwardTitle: Formation of Molecular Hydrogen and Water on Warm Grains
Award.AbstractNarration:
This investigation will study the formation of molecular hydrogen and water on warm (T>50 K) analogs of grains in the interstellar medium (ISM). The researchwill use state-of-the-art techniques to recreate in the laboratory the processes associated with the formation of these molecules on dust grains in space environments. Over the years, the Principal Investigator (PI) has built a group of collaborators who will: 1) provide characterized analogs of dust grains; 2) build ab-initio potentials to study the radical-surface interaction; and 3) implement stochastic methods to use laboratory derived quantities in models of the chemical evolution of space environments. This project is about the formation of two molecules: hydrogen (H2) and water. Molecular hydrogen - the most abundant molecule in space - is made almost exclusively on dust grains. The PI's laboratory conducted the first studies of hydrogen formation on dust analogs (amorphous and crystalline silicates, amorphous carbon and water ices) at low (5-30 K) temperature. But it is known that molecular hydrogen is also formed in environments where the dust temperature is higher (such as in protoplanetary disks) and that different mechanisms operate in these conditions. This project will extend the previous work by targeting the formation (mechanisms and efficiencies) of H2 formation on surfaces of amorphous silicates, polycyclics aromatic hydrocarbons, and graphitic carbon. There are currently no comprehensive studies of H2 formation on dust grain analogs at high (T>50K) temperature.

Water is a well-recognized pre-requisite for the complex chemistry linked to the emergence and sustainability of life; Interactions of atoms in the gas-phase cannot explain its abundance in the interstellar medium so it is hypothesized that water forms on the surface of interstellar dust grains. This research group is currently completing an NSF-sponsored study of the formation of water via the reaction of hydrogen and oxygen atoms with amorphous silicates and graphite at low temperature. This project will extend the investigation to water formation on grains at higher temperature (as, for example, in protoplanetary disks. This topic is important in understanding the delivery of water to and its incorporation in planets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
About 200 molecules have been detected in space so far. Two of those are particular important in understanding the physical and chemical evolution of the interstellar medium and of the formation of stars: molecular hydrogen and water. As it turns out, these two molecules form largely on submicron dust grains ("stardust"). How these molecules form, under what conditions, and what the implications are for the overall evolution of the chemical cosmos are the objective of this project.

Contrary to the formation of molecules in "empty" space, knowledge about  the formation of molecules on dust grains is much scarcer and more fragmented, both because the composition and morphology of grains are largely unknown, and because processes occurring at surfaces require a much more intimate investigation.

In our research, we investigates the formation of molecules (especially water, because of its importance in connection with astrobiology, and because of observational programs aimed at its detection is space;; and hydrogen, since it is the most abundant atoms and molecule) on "warm grains", i.e. when the temperature of grains i(T~50 K) is higher than the one in the densest clouds. Under these conditions, atoms from the gas-phase reside briefly on dust grains, making the observed formation of molecules challenging to explain.

Using a dedicated ultra-high vacuum apparatus capable of keeping samples at 5 K. - as required to replicate the conditions in space, we were able to study:

  • Processes of adsorption (sticking), diffusion and desorption of oxygen on/from warm dust grain analogs (silicates and water ices).
  • Formation of water on dust grain analogs through various reactions and conditions, such as via the reaction hydrogen and oxygen atoms.
  • Mechanism of hydrogen-addition reactions on water ices
  • Processes of sticking and desorption of key molecules on/from ices
  • Formation of molecules of interest to the emergence of life, such as hydroxylamine, a precursor to glycine, an amino acid.

Experimental research yielded information on physical and chemical processes and the determination of key quantities that are important in obtaining an overall picture of the evolution of the interstellar medium. Such quantities are, for example, the sticking coefficient of atoms/molecules on surfaces of grains under various conditions, and the binding energy of such molecules on dust grain analogs. We also carried out simulations to see the effect of such new determinations on the chemical evolution of certain astrophysical environments. Specifically, the problem of the non-detection of molecular oxygen in certain space environments was found to be linked to the adsorption energy of atomic oxygen on dust grains. Our experiments showed how a previous indirect determination of this energy was a factor two too small, yielding wrong conclusions on the availability of molecular oxygen in the gas-phase (i.e., much more oxygen is locked in grains than it was previously thought)..

The integration of experiments with theoretical developments can be particularly fruitful. For example, we showed how carefully designed experiments can yield information on the diffusion of atoms (oxygen) and molecules (CO2) on/in ices. Furthermore, using a new time-resolved reaction scattering technique, we were able to show the importance of the Eley-Rideal mechanism of reaction (direct abstraction of atoms from the surface)) in hydrogen addition reactions at surfaces. This result should spur new research on how to handle this reaction in simulations of reactions at surfaces in space environments.

The training of undergraduate and graduate students, and of post-docs, can be particular fruitful because, in order to conduct the research described above, students have to learn about and become proficient is using experimental and theoretical techniques in several fields, such as surface physics, chemical physics, and astrophysics.
